text-unit.text: In theamsmath package\boldsymbol is used for getting individual bold mathsymbols and bold Greek lettersâ€”everything in math except for letters of theLatin alphabet, where youâ€™d use\mathbf. For example,
looks like this:

If a bold version of a particular symbol doesnâ€™t exist in the available fonts, then\boldsymbol canâ€™t be used to make that symbol bold. At the present time, thismeans that\boldsymbol canâ€™t be used with symbols from themsam andmsbmfonts, among others. In some cases, poor manâ€™s bold (\pmb) can be used insteadof\boldsymbol:

So-called â€œlarge operatorâ€ symbols such as

TEX
book.
\iint,\iiint, and\iiiint give multiple integral signs with the spacing be-tween them nicely adjusted, in both text and display style. \idotsint givestwo integral signs with dots between them.

text-unit.text:
Some extra over and under arrow operations are provided in theamsmath pack-age. (Basic
LATEX
provides\overrightarrow and\overleftarrow).
These all scale properly in subscript sizes:

Normally you need only type\dots for ellipsis dots in a math formula. Themain exception is when the dots fall at the end of the formula; then you needto specify one of\dotsc (series dots, after a comma),\dotsb (binary dots, forbinary relations or operators),\dotsm (multiplication dots), or\dotsi (dotsafter an integral). For example, the input
produces

A1A2Â·Â·Â·
, and the infinite integral
Double accents:

This double accent operation is complicated and tends to slow down the pro-cessing of a
LATEX
file.

\dddot and\ddddot are available to produce triple and quadruple dot accentsin addition to the\dot and\ddot accents already available in
LATEX

The command\boxed puts a box around its argument, like\fbox except thatthe contents are in math mode:

\xleftarrow and\xrightarrow produce arrows that extend automatically toaccommodate unusually wide subscripts or superscripts. The text of the sub-script or superscript are given as an optional resp. mandatory argument: Ex-ample:
